docs.text:
The ABI-to-MCP Server Generator. Generate AI-ready interfaces for any smart contract in seconds.

UCAI converts Ethereum smart contract ABIs into Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers, enabling AI assistants like Claude to interact with DeFi protocols, NFTs, tokens, and any on-chain contract.

    abi-to-mcp generate 0xA0b86991c6218b36c1d19D4a2e9Eb0cE3606eB48 -n mainnet

docs.title: What is MCP?
docs.text:
The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is a standard for connecting AI assistants to external tools and data sources. When you generate an MCP server from a smart contract ABI, Claude can:

  • Query token balances, allowances, and contract state
  • Inspect NFT metadata and ownership
  • Simulate transactions before execution
  • Execute transfers, swaps, and other operations (with your approval)

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
from abi_to_mcp.parser import ABIParser
from abi_to_mcp.mapper import TypeMapper, FunctionMapper
from abi_to_mcp.generator import MCPGenerator

# Parse ABI
parser = ABIParser()
parsed = parser.parse(abi_json)

# Map to MCP tools
type_mapper = TypeMapper()
func_mapper = FunctionMapper(type_mapper)
tools = [func_mapper.map_function(f) for f in parsed.functions]

# Generate server
generator = MCPGenerator()
server = generator.generate(
    parsed=parsed,
    tools=tools,
    contract_address="0x...",
    network="mainnet"
)

# Write files
for file in server.files:
    Path(file.path).write_text(file.content)

docs.title: Pipeline Steps
docs.text:
1. Fetch ABI - Uses fetcher registry
  2. Parse ABI - Extracts functions and events
  3. Map to MCP - Converts to tools and resources
  4. Generate Code - Renders templates
  5. Write Files - Outputs to disk

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
async def _generate_async(source, output, network, ...):
    # Step 1: Fetch
    registry = create_default_registry()

    if is_valid_address(source):
        fetch_result = await registry.fetch(source, network=network)
    else:
        fetch_result = await registry.fetch(source)

    # Step 2: Parse
    parser = ABIParser()
    parsed = parser.parse(fetch_result.abi)

    # Step 3: Map
    type_mapper = TypeMapper()
    func_mapper = FunctionMapper(type_mapper)
    event_mapper = EventMapper(type_mapper)

    tools = [func_mapper.map_function(f) for f in parsed.functions]
    resources = [event_mapper.map_event(e) for e in parsed.events]

    # Step 4: Generate
    generator = MCPGenerator()
    server = generator.generate(parsed=parsed, tools=tools, ...)

    # Step 5: Write
    for file in server.files:
        (output / file.path).write_text(file.content)

    SourcifyFetcher,
    ABINotFoundError
)

async def fetch_with_fallback(address: str, network: str):
    # Try Etherscan first

        fetcher = EtherscanFetcher()

from abi_to_mcp.fetchers import ABIFetcher, FetchResult

class IPFSFetcher(ABIFetcher):
    """Fetch ABI from IPFS."""

    async def fetch(self, source: str, **kwargs) -> FetchResult:
        # source is IPFS CID
        url = f"https://ipfs.io/ipfs/{source}"
        async with httpx.AsyncClient() as client:
            response = await client.get(url)
            abi = response.json()

        return FetchResult(
            abi=abi,
            source="ipfs"
        )

    def can_handle(self, source: str) -> bool:
        return source.startswith("Qm") or source.startswith("bafy")

# Register

registry.register(IPFSFetcher())

docs.title: Complete Transaction Flow
docs.text:
from abi_to_mcp.runtime import (
    Web3Client,
    TransactionBuilder,
    TransactionSimulator,
    Signer
)

# Setup
client = Web3Client(network="mainnet")
contract = client.get_contract(address, abi)
builder = TransactionBuilder(client)
simulator = TransactionSimulator(client)
signer = Signer()

# Build function call
func = contract.functions.transfer(to_address, amount)

# Simulate first
sim_result = await simulator.simulate(func, signer.address)
if not sim_result["would_succeed"]:
    raise ValueError(f"Would fail: {sim_result['error']}")

print(f"Gas estimate: {sim_result['gas_estimate']}")
print(f"Cost: {sim_result['estimated_cost_eth']} ETH")

# Build and sign
tx = builder.build_transaction(func, signer.address)
signed = signer.sign_transaction(tx)

# Send
tx_hash = await client.w3.eth.send_raw_transaction(signed.rawTransaction)
print(f"Sent: {tx_hash.hex()}")

# Wait for receipt
receipt = await client.w3.eth.wait_for_transaction_receipt(tx_hash)
print(f"Confirmed in block {receipt['blockNumber']}")

docs.title: abi-to-mcp generate
docs.text: Generate a complete MCP server from a smart contract ABI.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: abi-to-mcp generate SOURCE [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The generate command is the core of abi-to-mcp. It takes an ABI source (contract address or file path), fetches/parses the ABI, and generates a complete MCP server with all tools and resources.

docs.title: SOURCE
docs.text:
The ABI source, which can be:

  • Contract address: 0x... - Fetches ABI from Etherscan/Sourcify
  • File path: ./contract.json - Loads ABI from local file
# From address
abi-to-mcp generate 0xA0b86991c6218b36c1d19D4a2e9Eb0cE3606eB48

# From file
abi-to-mcp generate ./artifacts/MyContract.json

docs.title: --output, -o
docs.text:
Output directory for the generated server.

Default ./mcp-server Type Path 
abi-to-mcp generate 0x... -o ./my-server

docs.title: --network, -n
docs.text:
Network for address lookups and configuration.

Default mainnet Choices mainnet, sepolia, goerli, polygon, arbitrum, optimism, base, bsc, avalanche, fantom 
abi-to-mcp generate 0x... -n polygon

docs.title: --address, -a
docs.text:
Contract address (required when SOURCE is a file).

Default None (extracted from address SOURCE) Type Ethereum address 
abi-to-mcp generate ./abi.json --address 0x1234...

docs.title: --name
docs.text:
Custom name for the generated server.

Default Auto-detected from contract Type String 
abi-to-mcp generate 0x... --name "My Token Server"

docs.title: --read-only
docs.text:
Generate only read operations (no write tools).

Default False Type Flag 
abi-to-mcp generate 0x... --read-only

Use for Safety

Use --read-only when you only need to query data and want to prevent any possibility of state-changing operations.

docs.title: --events / --no-events
docs.text:
Include or exclude events as MCP resources.

Default --events (included) Type Flag 
# Exclude events
abi-to-mcp generate 0x... --no-events

docs.title: --simulate / --no-simulate
docs.text:
Default simulation mode for write operations.

Default --simulate (simulation on) Type Flag 
# Disable simulation by default (dangerous!)
abi-to-mcp generate 0x... --no-simulate

Not Recommended

Disabling simulation by default means write tools will execute real transactions immediately. Only use this if you understand the risks.

docs.title: --rpc-url
docs.text:
Default RPC URL to embed in generated config.

Default Network-specific public RPC Type URL 
abi-to-mcp generate 0x... --rpc-url https://eth.llamarpc.com

docs.title: --force, -f
docs.text:
Overwrite existing output directory without prompting.

Default False (prompt before overwriting) Type Flag 
abi-to-mcp generate 0x... -o ./existing-dir --force

docs.text:

├── server.py           # Main MCP server

docs.title: Generated Tools
docs.text:
For each contract function, a corresponding MCP tool is generated:

Solidity MCP Tool Type function balanceOf(address) view returns (uint256) balance_of(account: str) -> str Read function transfer(address, uint256) returns (bool) transfer(to: str, amount: str, simulate: bool = True) -> dict Write function deposit() payable deposit(value: str, simulate: bool = True) -> dict Payable

docs.text:
For each event, an MCP resource is generated:

Solidity MCP Resource event Transfer(address indexed from, address indexed to, uint256 value) events://transfer event Approval(address indexed owner, address indexed spender, uint256 value) events://approval

docs.title: Proxy Contracts
docs.text:
abi-to-mcp automatically detects proxy contracts:

  • EIP-1967: Standard proxy pattern
  • EIP-1822: UUPS proxies
  • OpenZeppelin: TransparentProxy
  • EIP-1167: Minimal proxies (clones)

When a proxy is detected, the implementation ABI is fetched automatically.

# This will detect USDC is a proxy and fetch the implementation
abi-to-mcp generate 0xA0b86991c6218b36c1d19D4a2e9Eb0cE3606eB48 -n mainnet

  • Automatic dependency checking
  • Environment validation
  • Debug logging options

docs.title: Core Concepts
docs.text: This section explains the fundamental concepts you need to understand to work effectively with abi-to-mcp.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
abi-to-mcp bridges the gap between smart contracts and AI assistants. To do this effectively, it must handle several key challenges:

  1. Type Translation - Converting Solidity types to JSON Schema and Python
  2. Operation Classification - Distinguishing read vs write operations
  3. Event Handling - Exposing historical data through resources
  4. Safety - Preventing accidental or unauthorized transactions

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
• Type Mapping

    How Solidity types are converted to JSON Schema for validation and Python for code generation.

    Type Mapping

  • Tool Types

    The difference between read, write, and payable tools and how they're handled.

    Tool Types

  • Events & Resources

    How contract events become queryable MCP resources.

    Events

  • Safety Features

    Built-in protections for safe smart contract interaction.

    Safety

  • Security Scanner

    Detect rug pulls, honeypots, and 50+ risks before connecting your AI agent.

    Security Scanner

docs.title: The MCP Protocol
docs.text: The Model Context Protocol (MCP) defines how AI assistants connect to external tools. Key concepts:

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
Tools are functions the AI can call. In abi-to-mcp, each contract function becomes a tool:

Solidity Function → MCP Tool → AI Capability

For example: 

balanceOf(address) → balance_of tool → "Check token balance"

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
Resources are data sources the AI can query. In abi-to-mcp, events become resources:

Solidity Event → MCP Resource → Historical Data

For example: 

Transfer event → events://transfer → "Recent transfers"

docs.title: Schemas
docs.text:
Both tools and resources have JSON Schemas that define their parameters and return types. This allows:

  • Validation - Ensure inputs are correct before calling
  • Documentation - AI understands what parameters mean
  • Type Safety - Catch errors early

docs.title: The Generation Pipeline
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[ABI JSON] --> B[Parser]
    B --> C[Type Mapper]
    C --> D[Tool Generator]
    C --> E[Resource Generator]
    D --> F[MCP Server]
    E --> F

    style A fill:#627EEA,color:#fff
    style F fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff
  1. Parser - Reads ABI JSON and creates structured objects
  2. Type Mapper - Converts Solidity types to JSON Schema
  3. Tool Generator - Creates MCP tool definitions
  4. Resource Generator - Creates MCP resource definitions
  5. MCP Server - Complete runnable server

docs.title: Understanding ABIs
docs.text:
An ABI (Application Binary Interface) is a JSON description of a smart contract's interface:

[
  {
    "type": "function",
    "name": "balanceOf",
    "inputs": [{"name": "account", "type": "address"}],
    "outputs": [{"name": "", "type": "uint256"}],
    "stateMutability": "view"
  },
  {
    "type": "event",
    "name": "Transfer",
    "inputs": [
      {"name": "from", "type": "address", "indexed": true},
      {"name": "to", "type": "address", "indexed": true},
      {"name": "value", "type": "uint256", "indexed": false}
    ]
  }
]

abi-to-mcp reads this and generates corresponding MCP tools and resources.

docs.title: Events & Resources
docs.text: Smart contract events provide a historical record of what happened on the blockchain. abi-to-mcp exposes these as MCP resources that AI assistants can query.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Contract Event] --> B[Event Parser]
    B --> C[MCP Resource]
    C --> D[Historical Data]

    style A fill:#627EEA,color:#fff
    style C fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff

docs.title: What Are Events?
docs.text:
Events are logs emitted by smart contracts during transactions:

event Transfer(
    address indexed from,
    address indexed to,
    uint256 value
);

function transfer(address to, uint256 amount) external returns (bool) {
    // ... transfer logic ...
    emit Transfer(msg.sender, to, amount);
    return true;
}

Key properties: - Immutable - Once emitted, cannot be changed - Indexed Parameters - Up to 3 parameters can be indexed for efficient filtering - Gas Efficient - Cheaper than storage for historical data - Off-Chain Access - Can be queried without calling the contract

docs.title: Events as MCP Resources
docs.text: Each event becomes a queryable MCP resource:

docs.title: Resource URI Format
docs.text:
events://{event_name_snake_case}

Examples: - Transfer → events://transfer - Approval → events://approval - OwnershipTransferred → events://ownership_transferred

docs.title: Generated Resource
docs.text:
Solidity Event: 

event Transfer(
    address indexed from,
    address indexed to,
    uint256 value
);

MCP Resource: 

@mcp.resource("events://transfer")
async def get_transfer_events(
    from_address: str = None,
    to_address: str = None,
    from_block: int = None,
    to_block: int = None,
    limit: int = 100
) -> list[dict]:
    """
    Query Transfer events from the contract.

    Args:
        from_address: Filter by sender address (optional)
        to_address: Filter by recipient address (optional)
        from_block: Starting block number (optional)
        to_block: Ending block number (optional)
        limit: Maximum number of events to return

    Returns:
        List of Transfer events with block info
    """
    ...

docs.title: Indexed Parameters
docs.text:
• Can be used for filtering
  • Up to 3 per event
  • Stored as topics in the log
event Transfer(
    address indexed from,    // Can filter by this
    address indexed to,      // Can filter by this
    uint256 value           // Cannot filter by this
);

docs.title: Non-Indexed Parameters
docs.text:
• Cannot be used for filtering
  • Stored in log data
  • Still returned in results

docs.title: Get All Transfers
docs.text:
# AI can query: "Show me all transfers"
events = await get_transfer_events()

docs.title: Filter by Sender
docs.text:
# AI can query: "Show transfers from 0x123..."
events = await get_transfer_events(
    from_address="0x123..."
)

docs.title: Filter by Block Range
docs.text:
# AI can query: "Show transfers in the last 1000 blocks"
current_block = await w3.eth.block_number
events = await get_transfer_events(
    from_block=current_block - 1000,
    to_block=current_block
)

docs.title: Combined Filters
docs.text:
# AI can query: "Show transfers to 0x456... in last 100 blocks"
events = await get_transfer_events(
    to_address="0x456...",
    from_block=current_block - 100
)

docs.title: Event Data Structure
docs.text:
Each returned event includes:

{
    "event": "Transfer",
    "block_number": 18500000,
    "block_hash": "0x...",
    "transaction_hash": "0x...",
    "transaction_index": 42,
    "log_index": 7,
    "args": {
        "from": "0x123...",
        "to": "0x456...",
        "value": "1000000000000000000"
    }
}

docs.title: ERC20 Events
docs.text: Event Purpose Indexed Args Transfer(from, to, value) Token transfers from, to Approval(owner, spender, value) Spending approvals owner, spender

docs.title: ERC721 Events
docs.text: Event Purpose Indexed Args Transfer(from, to, tokenId) NFT transfers from, to, tokenId Approval(owner, approved, tokenId) Single approval owner, approved, tokenId ApprovalForAll(owner, operator, approved) Operator approval owner, operator

docs.text: Event Purpose Indexed Args ProposalCreated(proposalId, ...) New proposals proposalId VoteCast(voter, proposalId, ...) Votes voter, proposalId ProposalExecuted(proposalId) Execution proposalId

docs.title: Block Range Limits
docs.text:
Most RPC providers limit how many blocks you can query:

Provider Typical Limit Alchemy 2,000 blocks Infura 10,000 blocks QuickNode 10,000 blocks Public RPCs 1,000 blocks

Large Queries

Querying all events from block 0 will likely fail or timeout. Always use reasonable block ranges.

docs.title: Pagination
docs.text:
For large result sets, events are paginated:

# Get first 100 events
events = await get_transfer_events(limit=100)

# Get next 100 events (using last block as starting point)
last_block = events[-1]["block_number"]
more_events = await get_transfer_events(
    from_block=last_block,
    limit=100
)

docs.title: Excluding Events
docs.text:
If you don't need events, you can exclude them:

abi-to-mcp generate ./abi.json --no-events

This: - Reduces generated code size - Simplifies the server - Still includes all tools

docs.title: Anonymous Events
docs.text:
Anonymous events don't have a topic signature:

event AnonymousEvent(uint256 value) anonymous;

These are currently not supported by abi-to-mcp because they cannot be reliably filtered.

events = await get_transfer_events(

    from_block=expected_block - 10,
    to_block=expected_block + 10

# Check if expected transfer exists

docs.title: Safety Features
docs.text: abi-to-mcp is designed with safety as a primary concern. This page describes all the built-in protections.

docs.title: Safety Philosophy
docs.text:
Principle: No transaction should execute without explicit user intent.

Smart contract interactions are irreversible. Once a transaction is confirmed, it cannot be undone. abi-to-mcp provides multiple layers of protection:

graph TD
    A[User Request] --> B{Simulation}
    B -->|Pass| C{User Confirmation}
    B -->|Fail| D[Show Error]
    C -->|Confirmed| E{Private Key?}
    C -->|Rejected| F[Abort]
    E -->|Yes| G[Execute]
    E -->|No| H[Error: No Key]

    style B fill:#2196F3,color:#fff
    style C fill:#FF9800,color:#fff
    style G fill:#F44336,color:#fff

docs.title: Layer 1: Simulation by Default
docs.text:
All write operations simulate before executing:

@mcp.tool()
async def transfer(
    to: str,
    amount: str,
    simulate: bool = True  # Default: simulation only
) -> dict:
    """Transfer tokens."""
    if simulate:
        return await simulate_transaction(...)
    else:
        return await execute_transaction(...)

docs.title: What Simulation Shows
docs.text:
{
  "success": true,
  "would_succeed": true,
  "gas_estimate": 65000,
  "gas_price_gwei": 25.5,
  "estimated_cost_eth": "0.0016575",
  "estimated_cost_usd": "$3.15",
  "result": true
}

docs.title: Simulation Catches
docs.text:
• ✅ Insufficient balance
  • ✅ Insufficient allowance
  • ✅ Contract reverts
  • ✅ Invalid parameters
  • ✅ Access control failures

docs.title: Enabling Execution
docs.text:
Must explicitly set simulate=False:

# This WILL execute
result = await transfer(
    to="0x...",
    amount="1000000000000000000",
    simulate=False  # Explicit opt-in required
)

docs.title: Layer 2: Read-Only Mode
docs.text:
Generate servers that cannot write:

abi-to-mcp generate ./abi.json --read-only

This completely excludes: - All nonpayable functions - All payable functions - No private key handling code

Perfect for: - Exploration and research - Public-facing servers - Analytics dashboards

docs.title: Layer 3: No Embedded Keys
docs.text:
Private keys are never stored in generated code:

# config.py - generated
PRIVATE_KEY = os.environ.get("PRIVATE_KEY")  # From environment only

This means: - No keys in source control - No keys in generated files - Keys only loaded at runtime - Missing key = graceful error

docs.title: Missing Key Behavior
docs.text:
if not PRIVATE_KEY:
    return {
        "error": "PRIVATE_KEY not configured",
        "message": "Write operations require a private key. "
                   "Set the PRIVATE_KEY environment variable."
    }

docs.title: Layer 4: Transaction Validation
docs.text: Before any transaction:

docs.title: Address Validation
docs.text:
# Validates checksum and format
Web3.to_checksum_address(address)  # Raises if invalid

docs.title: Amount Validation
docs.text:
# Ensures positive integer
amount = int(amount_str)
if amount < 0:
    raise ValueError("Amount cannot be negative")

docs.title: Gas Validation
docs.text:
# Prevents runaway gas costs
if gas_estimate > MAX_GAS_LIMIT:
    raise ValueError(f"Gas estimate {gas_estimate} exceeds limit")

docs.title: Layer 5: Network Confirmation
docs.text:
Always confirms the network before writing:

# Verify chain ID matches expected
chain_id = await w3.eth.chain_id
if chain_id != EXPECTED_CHAIN_ID:
    raise NetworkMismatchError(
        f"Expected chain {EXPECTED_CHAIN_ID}, got {chain_id}"
    )

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Purpose Default PRIVATE_KEY Transaction signing None (disabled) SIMULATION_DEFAULT Default simulation mode true READ_ONLY_MODE Disable all writes false MAX_GAS_LIMIT Maximum gas per tx 500000 REQUIRE_CONFIRMATION Require explicit confirm true

docs.title: Generation Options
docs.text:
# Maximum safety
abi-to-mcp generate ./abi.json \
    --read-only \
    --no-events

# Standard safety (simulation default)
abi-to-mcp generate ./abi.json \
    --simulate

# Reduced safety (not recommended)
abi-to-mcp generate ./abi.json \
    --no-simulate

docs.title: For AI Assistants
docs.text:
Always Explain Risks

When a user asks to execute a transaction:

  1. Explain what the transaction will do
  2. Show the estimated gas cost
  3. Confirm the user wants to proceed
  4. Execute with simulate=False only after confirmation

docs.title: For Developers
docs.text:
Never Disable Simulation Globally

Always keep simulate=True as the default. Let users explicitly opt-in to execution.

docs.title: For Production
docs.text:
Dedicated Wallets

Never use a wallet containing significant funds. Create a dedicated wallet for MCP interactions with only the funds needed for operations.

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
All errors are caught and returned safely:

try:
    result = await execute_transaction(...)
except InsufficientFundsError as e:
    return {"error": "insufficient_funds", "message": str(e)}
except ContractRevertError as e:
    return {"error": "contract_revert", "message": str(e)}
except Exception as e:
    return {"error": "unknown", "message": str(e)}

docs.title: Audit Trail
docs.text:
All operations are logged:

logger.info(f"Simulating transfer: to={to}, amount={amount}")
logger.warning(f"Executing transfer: to={to}, amount={amount}")
logger.info(f"Transaction submitted: {tx_hash}")

docs.title: What abi-to-mcp Does NOT Protect Against
docs.text:
• Social engineering - User tricked into confirming bad transaction
  • Malicious contracts - ABI doesn't reveal malicious code
  • Private key theft - If environment is compromised
  • Phishing addresses - Similar-looking addresses

docs.title: What You Should Do
docs.text:
1. Verify contracts - Only use verified contracts
  2. Check addresses - Double-check recipient addresses
  3. Start small - Test with small amounts first
  4. Use hardware wallets - For significant funds
  5. Monitor transactions - Watch for unexpected activity

docs.title: Security Scanner
docs.text: The UCAI Security Scanner analyzes smart contracts for 50+ risk patterns before you create an MCP server. It helps you avoid connecting Claude to malicious or risky contracts.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
┌────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  🛡️ SECURITY REPORT                                         Score: 72/100    │
├────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                                                │
│  ⚠️  HIGH RISKS                                                                 │
│  ├── Mint Function — Owner may create unlimited tokens                        │
│  └── Pausable — Owner can freeze all transfers                                │
│                                                                                │
│  ⚡ MEDIUM RISKS                                                               │
│  ├── Proxy Contract — Logic can be upgraded                                   │
│  └── External Calls — Potential reentrancy vector                             │
│                                                                                │
│  ✅ POSITIVE INDICATORS                                                        │
│  ├── ✓ Contract verified on Etherscan                                         │
│  ├── ✓ Uses OpenZeppelin (audited library)                                    │
│  └── ✓ Has reentrancy protection                                              │
│                                                                                │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Risk Score
docs.text:
The scanner produces a score from 0 to 100:

Score Level Color Meaning 80-100 Safe 🟢 Green Standard patterns, low risk 60-79 Caution 🟡 Yellow Some concerns, review before proceeding 40-59 Warning 🟠 Orange Multiple risks, proceed carefully 0-39 Danger 🔴 Red High risk, likely malicious

docs.title: Scoring Logic
docs.text:
Each detected risk reduces the score:

Severity Points Deducted Critical -30 High -15 Medium -8 Low -3 Info -1

docs.title: 🚨 Critical Risks
docs.text:
These are the most dangerous patterns that often indicate malicious contracts:

Risk Pattern Description Self-Destruct selfdestruct, suicide Contract can be destroyed, draining all funds Arbitrary Delegatecall delegatecall(data) Can execute any code, complete takeover tx.origin Auth tx.origin Vulnerable to phishing attacks

docs.title: ⚠️ High Risks
docs.text:
Common rug pull and honeypot indicators:

Risk Pattern Description Hidden Mint function mint() Owner can create unlimited tokens Pause Function pause(), whenNotPaused Owner can freeze all transfers Blacklist blacklist, banned Owner can block specific addresses Adjustable Fees setFee(), setTax() Fees can be increased to 100% Transaction Limits maxTx, maxWallet Limits on buy/sell (honeypot indicator) Ownable Ownable without renounceOwnership Owner retains control

docs.title: ⚡ Medium Risks
docs.text:
Potential issues that require careful review:

Risk Pattern Description Transfer Restrictions require(!blacklist[]) Transfers may be blocked Hardcoded Owner owner = 0x... Owner is a fixed address External Calls .call(), .send() Potential reentrancy if unguarded Inline Assembly assembly { } Low-level code, harder to audit Proxy Pattern Upgradeable, Proxy Logic can change after deployment

docs.title: ℹ️ Low Risks
docs.text:
Minor issues or common patterns:

Risk Pattern Description Timestamp Dependence block.timestamp Minor manipulation by miners Unchecked Math unchecked { } Intentional gas optimization

docs.title: Positive Indicators
docs.text:
The scanner also detects good practices:

Indicator Pattern Meaning ✓ Verified API response Source code publicly verified ✓ OpenZeppelin @openzeppelin Uses audited library ✓ Reentrancy Guard ReentrancyGuard Protected from reentrancy ✓ Safe Math SafeMath, SafeERC20 Overflow/underflow protection ✓ Can Renounce renounceOwnership Owner can give up control ✓ SPDX License SPDX-License-Identifier Proper licensing ✓ Documentation @notice, @param NatSpec comments present

docs.title: Web Builder
docs.text:
1. Go to mcp.ucai.tech
  2. Enter a contract address
  3. Click Fetch ABI (auto-triggers scan) or 🛡️ Scan
  4. Review the security report
  5. Decide whether to proceed

docs.title: API
docs.text:
curl -X POST https://mcp.ucai.tech/api/analyze \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"address": "0x...", "network": "ethereum"}'

Response: 

{
  "securityReport": {
    "overallScore": 72,
    "riskLevel": "caution",
    "risks": [
      {
        "id": "hidden-mint",
        "severity": "high",
        "title": "Mint Function Detected",
        "description": "Owner may be able to create unlimited tokens"
      }
    ],
    "positives": [
      "✓ Contract is verified on block explorer",
      "✓ Uses OpenZeppelin (audited library)"
    ]
  }
}

docs.title: Proxy Contracts
docs.text:
The scanner automatically detects proxy contracts and:

  1. Identifies the implementation address
  2. Fetches the implementation's source code
  3. Analyzes the actual logic (not just the proxy)

This ensures you see the real risks, not just delegatecall.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
The security scanner is a heuristic tool, not a formal audit:

  • False positives: Some patterns (like mint) are dangerous in tokens but normal in NFTs
  • False negatives: Novel attack vectors may not be detected
  • Source required: Unverified contracts get a "Source Not Available" warning
  • No runtime analysis: Static analysis only, doesn't detect state-dependent issues

Always DYOR (Do Your Own Research) before interacting with any smart contract.

docs.title: Programmatic Access
docs.text:
The scanner logic is available in the security-scanner.ts module:

import { 
  generateSecurityReport, 
  analyzeSourceCode,
  analyzeAbi,
  calculateScore 
} from '@/lib/security-scanner';

const report = generateSecurityReport(
  address,
  sourceCode,
  abi,
  isVerified,
  contractName
);

console.log(report.overallScore);  // 72
console.log(report.riskLevel);     // "caution"
console.log(report.risks);         // [{...}]
console.log(report.positives);     // ["✓ Verified", ...]

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
To add new risk patterns:

  1. Edit web-v2/src/lib/security-scanner.ts
  2. Add to CRITICAL_PATTERNS, HIGH_PATTERNS, MEDIUM_PATTERNS, or LOW_PATTERNS
  3. Test with known malicious and legitimate contracts
  4. Submit a PR

Example: 

{
  id: "new-risk",
  pattern: /dangerousPattern/gi,
  title: "Dangerous Pattern",
  description: "This pattern indicates...",
}

docs.title: Tool Types
docs.text: abi-to-mcp generates different types of tools based on the function's state mutability. Understanding these types is crucial for safe smart contract interaction.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Function] --> B{stateMutability}
    B -->|pure/view| C[Read Tool]
    B -->|nonpayable| D[Write Tool]
    B -->|payable| E[Write Payable Tool]

    C --> F[No gas required]
    D --> G[Gas required]
    E --> H[Gas + ETH required]

    style C fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff
    style D fill:#FF9800,color:#fff
    style E fill:#F44336,color:#fff

docs.title: Read Tools
docs.text: Functions with pure or view state mutability become read tools.

docs.title: Characteristics
docs.text: Property Value Gas Required No Transaction No Private Key No Modifies State No Returns Data Yes

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Solidity: 

function balanceOf(address account) external view returns (uint256);

Generated Tool: 

@mcp.tool()
async def balance_of(account: str) -> str:
    """
    Get the token balance for an account.

    This is a read-only operation that does not require gas.

    Args:
        account: The address to check balance for (0x...)

    Returns:
        The token balance as a string (wei)
    """
    result = await contract.functions.balanceOf(
        Web3.to_checksum_address(account)
    ).call()
    return str(result)

docs.title: Common Read Functions
docs.text: Function Purpose balanceOf(address) Get token balance totalSupply() Get total supply name() Get token name symbol() Get token symbol decimals() Get token decimals allowance(owner, spender) Get spending approval ownerOf(tokenId) Get NFT owner

docs.title: Write Tools
docs.text: Functions with nonpayable state mutability become write tools.

docs.title: Characteristics
docs.text: Property Value Gas Required Yes Transaction Yes Private Key Yes Modifies State Yes Returns Transaction hash

docs.title: Safety Features
docs.text:
Write tools include built-in safety:

  1. Simulation by Default - Transactions are simulated before execution
  2. Explicit Opt-In - Must set simulate=False to execute
  3. Gas Estimation - Shows estimated gas cost before execution

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Solidity: 

function transfer(address to, uint256 amount) external returns (bool);

Generated Tool: 

@mcp.tool()
async def transfer(
    to: str,
    amount: str,
    simulate: bool = True
) -> dict:
    """
    Transfer tokens to another address.

    ⚠️ This operation modifies blockchain state and requires gas.

    Args:
        to: Recipient address (0x...)
        amount: Amount to transfer (in wei, as string)
        simulate: If True (default), only simulate the transaction

    Returns:
        If simulate=True: Simulation result with gas estimate
        If simulate=False: Transaction hash and receipt
    """
    if simulate:
        return await simulate_transaction(
            contract.functions.transfer(
                Web3.to_checksum_address(to),
                int(amount)
            )
        )
    else:
        return await execute_transaction(
            contract.functions.transfer(
                Web3.to_checksum_address(to),
                int(amount)
            )
        )

docs.text: Function Purpose transfer(to, amount) Transfer tokens approve(spender, amount) Approve spending transferFrom(from, to, amount) Transfer on behalf mint(to, amount) Create new tokens burn(amount) Destroy tokens

docs.text: Functions with payable state mutability become write payable tools.

docs.title: Characteristics

docs.text:
Payable tools include an additional value parameter:

async def deposit(
    value: str,  # ETH to send (in wei)
    simulate: bool = True
) -> dict:
    """
    Deposit ETH into the contract.

    ⚠️ This operation sends ETH and modifies blockchain state.

    Args:
        value: Amount of ETH to send (in wei, as string)
        simulate: If True (default), only simulate the transaction
    """
    ...

docs.text:
Solidity: 

function swap(
    address tokenIn,
    address tokenOut,
    uint256 amountIn
) external payable returns (uint256 amountOut);

Generated Tool:

async def swap(
    token_in: str,
    token_out: str,
    amount_in: str,
    value: str = "0",  # ETH to send
    simulate: bool = True

    """
    Swap tokens on the DEX.

    ⚠️ This operation may require sending ETH for gas and/or swap value.
    """

docs.text:
When safety is paramount, you can generate read-only servers:

abi-to-mcp generate ./abi.json --read-only

docs.title: Type Mapping
docs.text: Understanding how Solidity types are converted to JSON Schema is essential for working with generated MCP servers.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
abi-to-mcp performs a multi-step type conversion:

graph LR
    A[Solidity Type] --> B[Parsed Type]

docs.title: Numeric Types
docs.text:
Solidity Type JSON Schema Python Type Notes uint8 - uint256 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"} str String to preserve precision int8 - int256 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^-?[0-9]+$"} str String to preserve precision

Why Strings for Numbers?

JavaScript's Number type cannot safely represent values larger than 2^53. Since uint256 can be up to 2^256, we use strings to preserve precision across all systems.

docs.title: Address Types
docs.text:
Solidity Type JSON Schema Python Type address {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40}$"} str

The pattern ensures: - Starts with 0x - Exactly 40 hexadecimal characters - Case-insensitive (checksummed addresses work)

docs.title: Boolean Type
docs.text: Solidity Type JSON Schema Python Type bool {"type": "boolean"} bool

docs.title: Bytes Types
docs.text: Solidity Type JSON Schema Python Type Notes bytes {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]*$"} str Dynamic length bytes1 - bytes32 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{N}$"} str Fixed length (N = bytes * 2)

docs.title: String Type
docs.text: Solidity Type JSON Schema Python Type string {"type": "string"} str

docs.title: Array Types
Tuple Types (Structs)
docs.text:
Solidity structs are represented as tuples in the ABI:

// struct Order { address maker; uint256 amount; }
{
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "maker": {
      "type": "string",
      "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40}$"
    },
    "amount": {
      "type": "string",
      "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"
    }
  },
  "required": ["maker", "amount"]
}

docs.title: Type Parsing
docs.text:
The type parser handles complex nested types:

# Simple types
"uint256"     → BaseType("uint256")
"address"     → BaseType("address")

# Arrays
"uint256[]"   → ArrayType(BaseType("uint256"), None)
"address[5]"  → ArrayType(BaseType("address"), 5)

# Nested arrays
"uint256[][]" → ArrayType(ArrayType(BaseType("uint256"), None), None)

# Tuples (with components from ABI)
"tuple"       → TupleType([...components...])

docs.title: Empty Arrays
docs.text:
Empty arrays are valid for dynamic array types:

{
  "type": "array",
  "items": {"type": "string"}
}
// Valid: [], ["a"], ["a", "b"]

docs.title: Nested Tuples
docs.text:
Deeply nested structures are fully supported:

# struct Pool { Token tokenA; Token tokenB; uint24 fee; }
# struct Token { address addr; uint8 decimals; }

{
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "tokenA": {
      "type": "object",
      "properties": {
        "addr": {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40}$"},
        "decimals": {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"}
      }
    },
    "tokenB": {...},
    "fee": {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"}
  }
}

docs.title: Reserved Python Keywords
docs.text:
When Solidity parameter names conflict with Python keywords, they're automatically escaped:

Solidity Name Python Name from from_ class class_ import import_ type type_

docs.title: Custom Type Extensions
docs.text:
The type mapper can be extended for custom types:

from abi_to_mcp.mapper import TypeMapper

class CustomTypeMapper(TypeMapper):
    def to_json_schema(self, parsed_type) -> dict:
        # Handle custom type
        if parsed_type.base_type == "myCustomType":
            return {"type": "string", "format": "custom"}

        # Fall back to default
        return super().to_json_schema(parsed_type)

docs.title: 1. Fetching
docs.text:
registry = create_default_registry()
result = await registry.fetch("0x...")  # FetchResult

The registry: 1. Identifies source type (file, address) 2. Selects appropriate fetcher 3. Handles retries and fallbacks 4. Returns FetchResult with ABI and metadata

docs.title: 2. Parsing
docs.text:
parser = ABIParser()
parsed = parser.parse(result.abi)  # ParsedABI

The parser: 1. Iterates over ABI entries 2. Routes to specialized parser by type 3. Builds structured objects 4. Detects ERC standards 5. Returns ParsedABI

docs.title: 3. Mapping
docs.text:
type_mapper = TypeMapper()
func_mapper = FunctionMapper(type_mapper)

tools = [func_mapper.map_function(f) for f in parsed.functions]

The mapper: 1. Converts each function to MappedTool 2. Generates JSON Schema for parameters 3. Creates descriptions 4. Handles name conversion (camelCase → snake_case)

docs.title: 4. Generation
docs.text:
generator = MCPGenerator()
server = generator.generate(parsed, tools, resources, ...)

The generator: 1. Renders Jinja2 templates 2. Combines tools and resources 3. Generates config and docs 4. Returns GeneratedServer with all files

docs.title: 1. Strings for Large Numbers
docs.text:
All numeric types use JSON strings to preserve precision:

# uint256 as string, not int
{"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"}

Rationale: JavaScript's Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER is 2^53, but uint256 can be 2^256.

docs.title: 2. Simulation by Default
docs.text:
Write operations simulate before executing:

async def transfer(to, amount, simulate=True):
    if simulate:
        return await simulate_transaction(...)

Rationale: Blockchain transactions are irreversible. Simulation prevents accidents.

docs.title: 3. No Embedded Keys
docs.text:
Private keys are only read from environment:

PRIVATE_KEY = os.environ.get("PRIVATE_KEY")

Rationale: Never store secrets in generated code.

docs.title: 4. Jinja2 Templates
docs.text:
Code generation uses templates, not string concatenation:

@mcp.tool()
async def {{ tool.name }}({{ tool.signature }}):
    """{{ tool.description }}"""
    ...

Rationale: Templates are easier to read, maintain, and customize.

docs.title: 5. Async by Default
docs.text:
All I/O operations are async:

async def fetch(self, source: str) -> FetchResult:
    ...

Rationale: MCP servers are async, and blockchain calls can be slow.

# tests/unit/test_parser/test_type_parser.py
import pytest
from abi_to_mcp.parser import TypeParser


class TestTypeParser:
    """Tests for TypeParser."""

    def test_parse_simple_type(self):
        """Parse a simple type string."""
        parser = TypeParser()
        result = parser.parse("uint256")

        assert result.base_type == "uint256"
        assert result.is_array is False

    def test_parse_array_type(self):
        """Parse an array type."""
        parser = TypeParser()
        result = parser.parse("address[]")

        assert result.base_type == "address"
        assert result.is_array is True
        assert result.array_size is None

    def test_parse_fixed_array(self):
        """Parse a fixed-size array."""
        parser = TypeParser()
        result = parser.parse("bytes32[10]")

        assert result.array_size == 10

    @pytest.mark.parametrize("type_str,expected_base", [
        ("uint8", "uint8"),
        ("int256", "int256"),
        ("address", "address"),
        ("bool", "bool"),
        ("bytes", "bytes"),
        ("string", "string"),
    ])
    def test_parse_base_types(self, type_str, expected_base):
        """Parse various base types."""
        parser = TypeParser()
        result = parser.parse(type_str)
        assert result.base_type == expected_base

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: UCAI is a command-line tool (abi-to-mcp) and Python library that transforms Ethereum smart contract ABIs into fully functional MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers. These servers enable AI assistants like Claude to interact with any smart contract through a standardized interface.

docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have:

  • Python 3.10 or higher - Check with python --version

docs.title: Your First MCP Server
docs.text: Now that you've generated an MCP server, let's understand what was created and how it works.

docs.title: Generated File Structure
docs.text:
When you run abi-to-mcp generate, the following files are created:

my-mcp-server/
├── server.py           # Main MCP server implementation
├── config.py           # Configuration and environment variables
├── README.md           # Auto-generated documentation
├── requirements.txt    # Python dependencies
├── pyproject.toml      # Package metadata
└── .env.example        # Environment variable template

Let's explore each file.

docs.title: server.py - The MCP Server
docs.text: This is the heart of your generated server. It contains:

docs.title: Tool Definitions
docs.text:
Every contract function becomes an MCP tool:

@mcp.tool()
async def balance_of(account: str) -> str:
    """
    Get the token balance for an address.

    This is a read-only function (no gas required).

    Args:
        account: Ethereum address (20 bytes)

    Returns:
        Token balance as string (in wei)
    """
    result = await contract.functions.balanceOf(
        Web3.to_checksum_address(account)
    ).call()
    return str(result)

docs.title: Read vs Write Tools
docs.text:
Read-only functions (view/pure) are simple:

@mcp.tool()
async def name() -> str:
    """Get the token name. Read-only."""
    return await contract.functions.name().call()

Write functions include simulation by default:

@mcp.tool()
async def transfer(to: str, amount: str, simulate: bool = True) -> dict:
    """
    Transfer tokens to another address.

    ⚠️ This function modifies blockchain state and requires gas.

    Args:
        to: Recipient address
        amount: Amount in wei (as string)
        simulate: If True, only simulate the transaction

    Returns:
        Transaction result or simulation details
    """
    if simulate:
        # Simulate the transaction
        result = await simulate_transaction(
            contract.functions.transfer(to, int(amount))
        )
        return {"simulated": True, **result}
    else:
        # Execute real transaction
        tx = await execute_transaction(
            contract.functions.transfer(to, int(amount))
        )
        return {"simulated": False, "tx_hash": tx.hex()}

docs.title: Resource Definitions
docs.text:
Events become MCP resources for querying historical data:

@mcp.resource("events://transfer")
async def get_transfer_events(
    from_block: int = None,
    to_block: int = None
) -> list:
    """
    Query Transfer events from the contract.

    Args:
        from_block: Starting block number
        to_block: Ending block number (default: latest)

    Returns:
        List of Transfer events
    """
    events = await contract.events.Transfer.get_logs(
        fromBlock=from_block or "latest",
        toBlock=to_block or "latest"
    )
    return [format_event(e) for e in events]

docs.title: Understanding Tool Types
docs.text: The generated server classifies tools into three types:

docs.title: Read Tools (Safe)
docs.text:
• Call view or pure functions
  • No gas required
  • No wallet needed
  • Always safe to call
# Examples: balanceOf, name, symbol, totalSupply, allowance

docs.title: Write Tools (Requires Gas)
docs.text:
• Call state-changing functions
  • Require gas payment
  • Require private key
  • Simulate by default
# Examples: transfer, approve, transferFrom

docs.title: Payable Tools (Requires ETH)
docs.text:
• Call payable functions
  • Require both gas and ETH value
  • Extra careful simulation
# Examples: deposit (in WETH), mint (in some NFTs)

docs.title: Claude Desktop Integration
docs.text: This guide walks you through setting up abi-to-mcp generated servers with Claude Desktop for seamless blockchain interaction.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Claude Desktop installed
  • abi-to-mcp installed
  • A generated MCP server
  • RPC endpoint (Alchemy, Infura, or public)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Claude Desktop] <-->|MCP Protocol| B[Generated Server]
    B <-->|JSON-RPC| C[Blockchain]

    style A fill:#8B5CF6,color:#fff
    style B fill:#4CAF50,color:#fff
    style C fill:#627EEA,color:#fff

Claude Desktop communicates with MCP servers via the MCP protocol. Each server provides tools and resources that Claude can use to interact with smart contracts.

docs.title: Step 1: Generate a Server
docs.text:
If you haven't already:

# Example: USDC token
abi-to-mcp generate 0xA0b86991c6218b36c1d19D4a2e9Eb0cE3606eB48 \
    --network mainnet \
    --output ~/mcp-servers/usdc \
    --name "USDC Token"

docs.title: Step 2: Test the Server
docs.text:
Verify it works standalone:

cd ~/mcp-servers/usdc
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Set RPC URL
export RPC_URL="https://eth-mainnet.g.alchemy.com/v2/YOUR-KEY"

# Test run
python server.py

You should see: 

Starting USDC Token MCP Server...
Listening on stdio...

Press Ctrl+C to stop.

docs.title: Find the Config File
docs.text: OS Path macOS ~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json Windows %APPDATA%\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json Linux ~/.config/claude/claude_desktop_config.json

docs.title: Create or Edit Config
docs.text:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "usdc": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["/Users/yourname/mcp-servers/usdc/server.py"],
      "env": {
        "RPC_URL": "https://eth-mainnet.g.alchemy.com/v2/YOUR-KEY"
      }
    }
  }
}

Use Absolute Paths

Always use full absolute paths for the server script. Relative paths may not work correctly.

docs.title: Multiple Servers
docs.text:
Add more servers for different contracts or networks:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "usdc": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["/Users/yourname/mcp-servers/usdc/server.py"],
      "env": {
        "RPC_URL": "https://eth-mainnet.g.alchemy.com/v2/YOUR-KEY"
      }
    },
    "bayc": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["/Users/yourname/mcp-servers/bayc/server.py"],
      "env": {
        "RPC_URL": "https://eth-mainnet.g.alchemy.com/v2/YOUR-KEY"
      }
    },
    "uniswap": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["/Users/yourname/mcp-servers/uniswap/server.py"],
      "env": {
        "RPC_URL": "https://eth-mainnet.g.alchemy.com/v2/YOUR-KEY"
      }
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Step 4: Restart Claude Desktop
docs.text: Completely quit and reopen Claude Desktop. The servers will start automatically.

docs.title: Step 5: Verify Connection
docs.text:
In Claude Desktop, you should see the MCP icon indicating connected servers. Try a query:

"What's the USDC balance of vitalik.eth?"

Claude will use the balance_of tool from your USDC server.

docs.title: Checking Balances
docs.text:
You: What's the USDC balance of 0xd8dA6BF26964aF9D7eEd9e03E53415D37aA96045?

Claude: I'll check the USDC balance for that address.

[Uses balance_of tool]

The address 0xd8dA6BF26964aF9D7eEd9e03E53415D37aA96045 holds 1,234.56 USDC.

docs.title: Token Information
docs.text:
You: Tell me about this token

Claude: I'll get the token information.

[Uses name, symbol, decimals, total_supply tools]

Token Details: - Name: USD Coin - Symbol: USDC - Decimals: 6 - Total Supply: 26,234,567,890.00 USDC

docs.title: Simulating Transfers
docs.text:
You: What would happen if I transferred 100 USDC to 0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc9e7595f5b7A5?

Claude: I'll simulate that transfer for you.

[Uses transfer tool with simulate=True]

Simulation Result: - Would succeed: ✅ Yes - Gas estimate: 65,000 units - Estimated cost: ~0.002 ETH ($3.50)

Would you like me to execute this transfer?

docs.title: NFT Ownership
docs.text:
You: Who owns BAYC #1234?

Claude: I'll look up the owner of that NFT.

[Uses owner_of tool]

Bored Ape #1234 is owned by 0x123...

docs.title: Enabling Write Operations
docs.text: To allow Claude to execute transactions (not just simulate):

docs.title: 1. Add Private Key
docs.text:
In your config, add the private key environment variable:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "usdc": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["/path/to/server.py"],
      "env": {
        "RPC_URL": "https://...",
        "PRIVATE_KEY": "0x..."
      }
    }
  }
}

Security Warning

  • Never use a wallet with significant funds
  • Create a dedicated wallet for MCP interactions
  • Only fund it with what you're willing to risk

docs.title: 2. Confirm Execution
docs.text:
When you ask Claude to execute:

You: Transfer 10 USDC to 0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc9e7595f5b7A5

Claude: I'll simulate this transfer first.

[Simulation results...]

The simulation succeeded. This will: - Send 10 USDC to 0x742d... - Cost approximately 0.002 ETH in gas

Would you like me to proceed with the actual transfer?

You: Yes, proceed

Claude: [Executes transfer with simulate=False]

✅ Transfer complete! Transaction: 0xabc123...

docs.title: Server Not Connecting
docs.text:
Check the Claude Desktop logs:

# macOS
tail -f ~/Library/Logs/Claude/mcp*.log

# Linux
tail -f ~/.local/share/claude/logs/mcp*.log

Common issues: - Wrong path to server.py - Missing dependencies - Invalid RPC URL

docs.title: "Tool not found"
docs.text:
• Restart Claude Desktop
  • Check server is in config
  • Verify server starts without errors

docs.title: RPC Errors
docs.text:
• Check RPC URL is valid
  • Verify API key has sufficient credits
  • Try a different RPC provider

docs.title: Slow Responses
docs.text:
• RPC endpoint may be rate-limited
  • Use a paid RPC plan
  • Consider caching for repeated queries

docs.title: 1. Use Read-Only for Exploration
docs.text:
Generate read-only servers when you don't need writes:

abi-to-mcp generate 0x... --read-only --output ./explorer

docs.title: 2. Separate Private Keys
docs.text: Use different wallets for different purposes: - Testing wallet (small funds) - Production wallet (monitored) - Never your main wallet

docs.title: 3. Monitor Usage
docs.text: Check your RPC provider dashboard for: - API usage - Rate limits - Errors

docs.title: 4. Keep Servers Updated
docs.text:
When contract ABIs change:

# Regenerate
abi-to-mcp generate 0x... --output ./my-server --force

docs.title: Custom Python Path
docs.text:
If using a virtual environment:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "usdc": {
      "command": "/path/to/venv/bin/python",
      "args": ["/path/to/server.py"],
      "env": {
        "RPC_URL": "..."
      }
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Working Directory
docs.text:
Set a working directory:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "usdc": {
      "command": "python",
      "args": ["server.py"],
      "cwd": "/path/to/usdc-server",
      "env": {
        "RPC_URL": "..."
      }
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Environment File
docs.text:
For many environment variables:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "usdc": {
      "command": "bash",
      "args": ["-c", "source .env && python server.py"],
      "cwd": "/path/to/usdc-server"
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Custom Network Guide
docs.text:
abi-to-mcp supports many networks out of the box, but you may need to add custom networks for:

  • Private/enterprise blockchains
  • New L2s not yet added
  • Testnets
  • Local development chains

docs.title: Built-in Networks
docs.text:
These networks are supported by default:

Network Chain ID Flag Ethereum Mainnet 1 --network mainnet Goerli Testnet 5 --network goerli Sepolia Testnet 11155111 --network sepolia Polygon 137 --network polygon Polygon Mumbai 80001 --network mumbai Arbitrum One 42161 --network arbitrum Optimism 10 --network optimism Base 8453 --network base BSC 56 --network bsc Avalanche C-Chain 43114 --network avalanche

docs.title: Using Custom RPC
docs.text:
The simplest way to use any network is providing a custom RPC URL:

# Generate with default (for ABI fetching)
abi-to-mcp generate ./my-abi.json \
    --output ./my-server \
    --address 0x1234...

Then set the custom RPC in .env:

RPC_URL=https://your-custom-rpc.example.com
CHAIN_ID=12345

docs.title: Adding a Custom Network
docs.text: For networks with Etherscan-compatible explorers, you can configure full support.

docs.title: Method 1: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Set these before running:

# Custom network configuration
export CUSTOM_CHAIN_ID=324
export CUSTOM_RPC_URL=https://mainnet.era.zksync.io
export CUSTOM_EXPLORER_URL=https://api.zkscan.io/api
export CUSTOM_EXPLORER_API_KEY=your-api-key

# Now generate
abi-to-mcp generate 0x1234... \
    --network custom \
    --output ./zksync-server

docs.title: Method 2: Network Configuration File
docs.text:
Create ~/.abi-to-mcp/networks.json:

{
  "networks": {
    "zksync": {
      "name": "zkSync Era",
      "chain_id": 324,
      "rpc_url": "https://mainnet.era.zksync.io",
      "explorer_url": "https://api.zkscan.io/api",
      "explorer_api_key_env": "ZKSYNC_API_KEY",
      "currency": {
        "name": "Ether",
        "symbol": "ETH",
        "decimals": 18
      }
    },
    "linea": {
      "name": "Linea",
      "chain_id": 59144,
      "rpc_url": "https://rpc.linea.build",
      "explorer_url": "https://api.lineascan.build/api",
      "explorer_api_key_env": "LINEA_API_KEY",
      "currency": {
        "name": "Ether",
        "symbol": "ETH",
        "decimals": 18
      }
    }
  }
}

Now use the network name:

abi-to-mcp generate 0x1234... --network zksync

docs.title: Private Enterprise Chains
docs.text: For private networks without public explorers:

docs.title: 1. Get ABI Locally
docs.text:
You'll need the ABI file since there's no explorer:

# From Hardhat

# Optional: Authentication

# config.py
import os

RPC_URL = os.environ.get("RPC_URL")
RPC_AUTH_HEADER = os.environ.get("RPC_AUTH_HEADER")

# In web3_client initialization
if RPC_AUTH_HEADER:
    headers = {"Authorization": RPC_AUTH_HEADER}
    # Configure Web3 with custom headers

docs.title: DeFi Protocol Guide
docs.text:
This guide covers creating MCP servers for complex DeFi protocols like Uniswap, Aave, and Compound. These protocols have:

  • Multiple contracts
  • Complex parameters (structs, arrays)
  • Payable functions
  • Time-sensitive operations

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• abi-to-mcp installed
  • Good understanding of Core Concepts
  • RPC endpoint with archive access (recommended)

docs.title: Example: Uniswap V3 Router
docs.text:
Uniswap's SwapRouter is one of the most used DeFi contracts:

Property Value Contract SwapRouter Address 0xE592427A0AEce92De3Edee1F18E0157C05861564 Network Ethereum Mainnet

docs.title: Generate the Server
docs.text:
abi-to-mcp generate 0xE592427A0AEce92De3Edee1F18E0157C05861564 \
    --network mainnet \
    --output ./uniswap-router \
    --name "Uniswap V3 Router"

docs.title: Key Functions
docs.text: Function Purpose Parameters exactInputSingle Swap exact input for output ExactInputSingleParams struct exactOutputSingle Swap for exact output ExactOutputSingleParams struct exactInput Multi-hop exact input Encoded path exactOutput Multi-hop exact output Encoded path

docs.title: Struct Parameters
docs.text:
Uniswap uses complex struct parameters:

# ExactInputSingleParams
{
    "tokenIn": "0xC02aaA39b223FE8D0A0e5C4F27eAD9083C756Cc2",  # WETH
    "tokenOut": "0xA0b86991c6218b36c1d19D4a2e9Eb0cE3606eB48", # USDC
    "fee": "3000",        # 0.3% fee tier
    "recipient": "0x...",  # Your address
    "deadline": "1699999999",  # Unix timestamp
    "amountIn": "1000000000000000000",  # 1 WETH
    "amountOutMinimum": "1800000000",    # Min 1800 USDC
    "sqrtPriceLimitX96": "0"  # No price limit
}

docs.title: Fee Tiers
docs.text:
Uniswap V3 has multiple fee tiers:

Fee Value Best For 0.01% 100 Stable pairs (USDC/USDT) 0.05% 500 Stable pairs 0.3% 3000 Most pairs 1% 10000 Exotic pairs

docs.title: Example: Aave V3 Pool
docs.text:
Aave's lending pool enables deposits, borrows, and repayments:

Property Value Contract Pool Address 0x87870Bca3F3fD6335C3F4ce8392D69350B4fA4E2 Network Ethereum Mainnet

docs.title: Generate the Server
docs.text:
abi-to-mcp generate 0x87870Bca3F3fD6335C3F4ce8392D69350B4fA4E2 \
    --network mainnet \
    --output ./aave-pool \
    --name "Aave V3 Pool"

docs.title: Key Functions
docs.text: Function Type Purpose supply Write Deposit assets withdraw Write Withdraw assets borrow Write Borrow assets repay Write Repay debt getUserAccountData Read Get user health factor getReserveData Read Get asset info

docs.title: Reading User Data
docs.text:
# Get user's account summary
data = await get_user_account_data(user="0x...")

# Returns:
{
    "totalCollateralBase": "10000000000",    # In base currency (USD, 8 decimals)
    "totalDebtBase": "5000000000",
    "availableBorrowsBase": "2500000000",
    "currentLiquidationThreshold": "8250",   # 82.5%
    "ltv": "8000",                           # 80%
    "healthFactor": "1650000000000000000"    # 1.65
}

Health Factor

If healthFactor falls below 1000000000000000000 (1.0), the position can be liquidated!

docs.title: Working with Multiple Contracts
docs.text: DeFi protocols often require multiple contracts:

docs.title: Uniswap Complete Setup
docs.text:
# Router for swaps
abi-to-mcp generate 0xE592427A0AEce92De3Edee1F18E0157C05861564 \
    -o ./uniswap/router -n mainnet

# Quoter for quotes (read-only)
abi-to-mcp generate 0xb27308f9F90D607463bb33eA1BeBb41C27CE5AB6 \
    -o ./uniswap/quoter -n mainnet --read-only

# Factory for pool lookups
abi-to-mcp generate 0x1F98431c8aD98523631AE4a59f267346ea31F984 \
    -o ./uniswap/factory -n mainnet --read-only

docs.title: Combined Server
docs.text:
You can combine multiple contracts into one server by editing the generated code:

# server.py
from uniswap.router.server import router_tools
from uniswap.quoter.server import quoter_tools
from uniswap.factory.server import factory_tools

# Register all tools
for tool in router_tools + quoter_tools + factory_tools:
    mcp.register_tool(tool)

docs.title: Token Approvals
docs.text:
Most DeFi operations require token approvals first:

sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Token
    participant Protocol

    User->>Token: approve(protocol, amount)
    Token-->>User: ✓ Approved
    User->>Protocol: deposit(amount)
    Protocol->>Token: transferFrom(user, protocol, amount)
    Token-->>Protocol: ✓ Transferred
    Protocol-->>User: ✓ Deposited

docs.title: Check Allowance
docs.text:
# Check current allowance
allowance = await token_allowance(
    owner="0x...",
    spender="0x...protocol..."
)

if int(allowance) < amount_needed:
    # Need to approve first
    await token_approve(
        spender="0x...protocol...",
        amount="115792089237316195423570985008687907853269984665640564039457584007913129639935",  # Max uint256
        simulate=True
    )

Max Approval

Many users approve the maximum uint256 value to avoid repeated approvals. This is convenient but less secure.

docs.title: Handling Deadlines
docs.text:
Time-sensitive DeFi operations include deadlines:

import time

# Set deadline 20 minutes from now
deadline = str(int(time.time()) + 20 * 60)

result = await exact_input_single(
    params={
        "tokenIn": "0x...",
        "tokenOut": "0x...",
        "fee": "3000",
        "recipient": "0x...",
        "deadline": deadline,  # Important!
        "amountIn": "1000000000000000000",
        "amountOutMinimum": "0",
        "sqrtPriceLimitX96": "0"
    },
    simulate=True
)

Expired Deadlines

If the deadline passes before the transaction is mined, it will revert. Set reasonable deadlines based on network congestion.

docs.title: Slippage Protection
docs.text:
Always set minimum output amounts:

# Get quote first
quote = await quote_exact_input_single(
    tokenIn="0x...",
    tokenOut="0x...",
    fee="3000",
    amountIn="1000000000000000000",
    sqrtPriceLimitX96="0"
)

# Calculate minimum with 0.5% slippage
amount_out = int(quote)
slippage = 0.005
amount_out_minimum = str(int(amount_out * (1 - slippage)))

# Execute swap with protection
result = await exact_input_single(
    params={
        # ...
        "amountOutMinimum": amount_out_minimum
    }
)

docs.title: Flash Loans
docs.text:
Some protocols support flash loans (borrow + repay in one transaction). These require custom contract interactions beyond basic MCP tools.

Advanced Feature

Flash loans typically require writing custom smart contracts to execute the borrowed funds logic.

docs.title: Gas Optimization
docs.text:
DeFi transactions can be gas-intensive:

Operation Typical Gas Token approval 45,000 Simple swap 150,000 Multi-hop swap 250,000+ Aave supply 200,000 Aave borrow 300,000

Tips: - Batch operations when possible - Time transactions for low gas periods - Use gas estimation before executing

# Always simulate first to get gas estimate
result = await exact_input_single(params={...}, simulate=True)
print(f"Estimated gas: {result['gas_estimate']}")
print(f"Estimated cost: {result['estimated_cost_eth']} ETH")

docs.title: "INSUFFICIENT_OUTPUT_AMOUNT"
docs.text: Slippage too high or pool price moved. Solutions: - Increase amountOutMinimum tolerance - Use smaller trade sizes - Try different fee tiers

docs.title: "EXPIRED"
docs.text: Transaction wasn't mined before deadline: - Increase deadline - Increase gas price - Check network congestion

docs.title: "STF" (Safe Transfer Failed)
docs.text: Token transfer failed. Check: - Sufficient balance - Sufficient allowance - Token isn't paused

docs.title: "UNPREDICTABLE_GAS_LIMIT"
docs.text: Can't estimate gas (transaction would fail): - Simulation will help identify the issue - Check all parameters are valid - Verify contract state

docs.text:
Extend the parser to detect custom standards:

from abi_to_mcp.parser import ABIParser

class CustomParser(ABIParser):
    def detect_standard(self, functions, events):
        # Check for custom standard
        func_names = {f.name for f in functions}

        if "myCustomFunction" in func_names:
            return "MyCustomStandard"

        # Fall back to default detection
        return super().detect_standard(functions, events)

docs.title: Errors & Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common errors and how to resolve them.

docs.title: Error Categories
docs.text: Category Description ABIError Base error for all ABI-related issues ABINotFoundError ABI could not be retrieved ABIParseError ABI JSON structure is invalid ABIValidationError ABI content is invalid NetworkError Network/RPC related issues GenerationError Code generation failed

docs.title: Contract source code not verified
docs.text:
ABINotFoundError: Contract source code not verified

Cause: The contract is not verified on the block explorer.

Solutions:

  1. Use a local ABI file if you have one: 

    abi-to-mcp generate ./abi.json -a 0x...

  2. Try Sourcify which may have the contract: 

    abi-to-mcp generate 0x... --prefer-sourcify

  3. Verify the contract on Etherscan if you're the owner

docs.title: API rate limit exceeded
docs.text:
NetworkError: API rate limit exceeded. Please try again later.

Cause: Too many API requests to the block explorer.

Solutions:

  1. Use an API key: 

    export ETHERSCAN_API_KEY=your-key-here

  2. Wait and retry - rate limits usually reset quickly

  3. Use a paid API plan for higher limits

docs.title: Invalid address format
docs.text:
ABIValidationError: Invalid address format: 0x123

Cause: The address is not a valid Ethereum address.

Solutions:

  1. Check address length - must be 42 characters (0x + 40 hex)
  2. Check for typos in the address
  3. Include 0x prefix

docs.title: Network not found
docs.text:
NetworkError: Unknown network: mynetwork

Cause: The specified network is not configured.

Solutions:

  1. Check network name - use --network mainnet, not --network ethereum

  2. See available networks: 

    abi-to-mcp networks list

  3. Add custom network - see Custom Networks Guide

docs.title: Invalid ABI structure
docs.text:
ABIParseError: Invalid ABI: expected array, got object

Cause: The ABI is not a valid JSON array.

Solutions:

  1. Check file format - ABI should be a JSON array: 

    [{"type": "function", ...}, ...]

  2. Extract from artifact - Hardhat/Truffle artifacts wrap ABI: 

    abi = artifact["abi"]  # Extract ABI array

docs.title: Unknown type
docs.text:
ABIParseError: Unknown Solidity type: myCustomType

Cause: A custom or non-standard type was found.

Solutions:

  1. Check ABI source - may be corrupted or modified

  2. User-defined types are typically tuples in the ABI: 

    {"name": "param", "type": "tuple", "components": [...]}

docs.title: Missing required field
docs.text:
ABIValidationError: Missing required field 'type' in ABI entry

Cause: An ABI entry is missing required fields.

Solutions:

  1. Validate ABI format using: 

    abi-to-mcp validate ./abi.json

  2. Check ABI source - may be truncated or corrupted

docs.title: Output directory exists
docs.text:
GenerationError: Output directory already exists: ./my-server

Cause: The output directory is not empty.

Solutions:

  1. Use --force to overwrite: 

    abi-to-mcp generate 0x... -o ./my-server --force

  2. Choose different directory: 

    abi-to-mcp generate 0x... -o ./my-server-v2

docs.title: Template error
docs.text:
GenerationError: Template rendering failed: undefined variable 'xyz'

Cause: Custom template has an error.

Solutions:

  1. Check custom templates for syntax errors
  2. Use default templates by removing custom template config
  3. Check variable names match available context

docs.title: Could not connect to RPC
docs.text:
NetworkError: Could not connect to RPC: https://...

Cause: The RPC endpoint is unreachable.

Solutions:

  1. Check RPC URL is correct
  2. Check network connectivity
  3. Try a different RPC provider
  4. Check API key if using authenticated endpoint

docs.title: execution reverted
docs.text:
ContractRevertError: execution reverted: ERC20: transfer amount exceeds balance

Cause: The contract function reverted.

Common Causes:

Message Meaning transfer amount exceeds balance Not enough tokens insufficient allowance Need to approve first Ownable: caller is not the owner Only owner can call Pausable: paused Contract is paused

Solutions:

  1. Check balances before transferring
  2. Check allowances before transferFrom
  3. Verify permissions for restricted functions
  4. Check contract state (paused, etc.)

docs.title: Insufficient funds for gas
docs.text:
InsufficientFundsError: Insufficient funds for gas * price + value

Cause: Not enough ETH for transaction gas.

Solutions:

  1. Add ETH to your wallet
  2. Reduce gas price (may take longer)
  3. Use simulation to estimate cost first

docs.title: Nonce too low
docs.text:
TransactionError: nonce too low

Cause: Transaction with this nonce already mined.

Solutions:

  1. Wait for pending transactions to confirm
  2. Get current nonce from chain: 
    nonce = await w3.eth.get_transaction_count(address)

docs.title: Chain ID mismatch
docs.text:
NetworkError: Chain ID mismatch: expected 1, got 137

Cause: Connected to wrong network.

Solutions:

  1. Check RPC URL matches intended network
  2. Check chain ID in configuration
  3. Use correct network flag: 
    abi-to-mcp generate 0x... -n polygon  # Not mainnet

docs.title: Generation Issues
docs.text:
• [ ] Is the ABI source valid? (abi-to-mcp validate)
  • [ ] Is the address correct format?
  • [ ] Is the network specified correctly?
  • [ ] Do you have an API key set?
  • [ ] Is the output directory writable?

docs.title: Runtime Issues
docs.text:
• [ ] Is RPC_URL set correctly?
  • [ ] Is the RPC endpoint accessible?
  • [ ] Is PRIVATE_KEY set (for writes)?
  • [ ] Do you have sufficient balance?
  • [ ] Are you on the correct network?

docs.title: Contract Issues
docs.text:
• [ ] Is the contract verified?
  • [ ] Is the contract address correct?
  • [ ] Is the contract on this network?
  • [ ] Is the ABI up to date?

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you can't resolve an issue:

  1. Check existing issues: GitHub Issues

  2. Open a new issue with:

  3. Full error message
  4. Command or code used
  5. ABI file (if not from verified contract)

  6. Network and address

  7. Enable debug logging: 

    export ABI_TO_MCP_LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG
abi-to-mcp generate 0x...

docs.title: Type Mapping Table
docs.text: Complete reference for how Solidity types are mapped to JSON Schema.

docs.title: Unsigned Integers
docs.text: Solidity JSON Schema Python Notes uint8 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"} str 0 to 255 uint16 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"} str 0 to 65,535 uint24 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"} str Used for Uniswap fees uint32 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"} str 0 to 4.29B uint64 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"} str Common for timestamps uint128 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"} str Large numbers uint256 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"} str Most common

docs.title: Signed Integers
docs.text:
Solidity JSON Schema Python Notes int8 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^-?[0-9]+$"} str -128 to 127 int16 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^-?[0-9]+$"} str -32,768 to 32,767 int24 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^-?[0-9]+$"} str Uniswap tick int32 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^-?[0-9]+$"} str Standard signed int64 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^-?[0-9]+$"} str Large signed int128 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^-?[0-9]+$"} str Very large signed int256 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^-?[0-9]+$"} str Maximum signed

Why Strings for Numbers?

JSON numbers have precision limits (~15-17 significant digits). Solidity integers can be up to 256 bits (78 digits). Using strings preserves full precision.

docs.title: Address Type
docs.text:
Solidity JSON Schema Python address {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40}$"} str

Valid examples: 

0xA0b86991c6218b36c1d19D4a2e9Eb0cE3606eB48  ✓
0xa0b86991c6218b36c1d19d4a2e9eb0ce3606eb48  ✓ (lowercase OK)
0xA0B86991C6218B36C1D19D4A2E9EB0CE3606EB48  ✓ (uppercase OK)

Invalid examples: 

A0b86991c6218b36c1d19D4a2e9Eb0cE3606eB48   ✗ (missing 0x)
0xA0b86991c6218b36c1d19D4a2e9Eb0cE3606eB4  ✗ (39 chars)

docs.title: Boolean Type
docs.text:
Solidity JSON Schema Python bool {"type": "boolean"} bool

Valid examples: 

true   ✓
false  ✓

docs.title: Fixed-Size Bytes
docs.text: Solidity JSON Schema Python Hex Length bytes1 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{2}$"} str 2 bytes2 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{4}$"} str 4 bytes4 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{8}$"} str 8 bytes8 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{16}$"} str 16 bytes16 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{32}$"} str 32 bytes20 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40}$"} str 40 bytes32 {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{64}$"} str 64

docs.title: Dynamic Bytes
docs.text:
Solidity JSON Schema Python bytes {"type": "string", "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]*$"} str

Valid examples: 

0x                         ✓ (empty bytes)
0x1234                     ✓
0xabcdef0123456789         ✓

docs.title: String Type
docs.text:
Solidity JSON Schema Python string {"type": "string"} str

No pattern validation - any string is valid.

docs.title: Dynamic Arrays
Fixed-Size Arrays
Nested Arrays
Tuple Types (Structs)
docs.text:
Tuples are mapped to JSON objects:

Solidity JSON Schema Python tuple {"type": "object", "properties": {...}, "required": [...]} Dict[str, Any]

Example:

Solidity struct: 

struct SwapParams {
    address tokenIn;
    address tokenOut;
    uint24 fee;
    uint256 amountIn;
}

JSON Schema: 

{
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "tokenIn": {
      "type": "string",
      "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40}$"
    },
    "tokenOut": {
      "type": "string",
      "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{40}$"
    },
    "fee": {
      "type": "string",
      "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"
    },
    "amountIn": {
      "type": "string",
      "pattern": "^[0-9]+$"
    }
  },
  "required": ["tokenIn", "tokenOut", "fee", "amountIn"]
}

docs.title: Function Selectors
docs.text:
bytes4 is commonly used for function selectors:

{
  "type": "string",
  "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{8}$",
  "description": "Function selector (4 bytes)"
}

docs.title: Merkle Proofs
docs.text:
bytes32[] is commonly used for Merkle proofs:

{
  "type": "array",
  "items": {
    "type": "string",
    "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]{64}$"
  },
  "description": "Merkle proof (array of 32-byte hashes)"
}

docs.title: Calldata
docs.text:
bytes is used for encoded calldata:

{
  "type": "string",
  "pattern": "^0x[a-fA-F0-9]*$",
  "description": "Encoded function call data"
}

docs.title: Invalid Inputs
docs.text:
# address - missing 0x prefix
"A0b86991c6218b36c1d19D4a2e9Eb0cE3606eB48"  ✗

# uint256 - native number (loses precision)
1000000000000000000  ✗

# uint256 - negative not allowed
"-1"  ✗

# bool - string instead of boolean
"true"  ✗

# bytes32 - wrong length
"0x01"  ✗
